section.title: Introduction
section.para: The HTTP Connection Pool Service allows Repose to manage and reuse HTTP connections. The service is using Apache Connection Management.

section.title: HTTP Connection Pool Configuration Options
section.para: The HTTP Connection Pool Service is used internally by Repose for communicating to the origin service. It is also used by the Distributed Datastore Service. The HTTP Connection Pool Service is used by default and does NOT need to be included in the System Model. To customize http connection pooling defaults, an optional http-connection-pool.cfg.xml can be provided.
An example configuration is provided: Example Http Connection Pool Configuration. The schema (XSD) is located here: http-connection-pool.xsd
Repose will use a default set of connection pool configurations, but these can be customized via an http-connection-pool.cfg.xml config file.

listitem.para: id - unique name of this set of pool configurations.
default - true/false indicates whether this is the default pool to use. Currently only 1 pool configuration is supported.

keepalive.timeout - Some HTTP servers use a non-standard Keep-Alive header to communicate to the client the period of time in seconds they intend to keep the connection alive on the server side. If this header is present in the response, the value in this header will be used to determine the maximum length of time to keep a persistent connection open for. If the Keep-Alive header is NOT present in the response, the value of keepalive.timeout is evaluated. If this value is 0, the connection will be kept alive indefinitely. If the value is greater than 0, the connection will be kept alive for the number of milliseconds specified.

chunked-encoding (Repose v2.10) - Requests going through repose have the possibility of having their request bodies being modified by filters. Due to this possibility Repose will, by default, send requests with entities as chunked. Setting 'chunked-encoding' to false will cause Repose to attempt to evaluate the actual content length of the request by reading the Servlet Input stream.

note.para: Reading the Servlet Input Stream will allow Repose to send a content-length header and not send messages chunked. This will cause some performance degradation as the request body will now always be read as instead to being streamed through.

section.para: Please refer to Apache Connection Management for descriptions of the http.* parameters.
